questions.text: In cases of suspected ectopic pregnancy, which hormone is typically measured?
What is the most effective approach to managing mild nausea and vomiting in pregnancy?

A female presents to you with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, complaining of bleeding per vagina and slight abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is slightly positive, and the hCG level is 2800 IU/L. A mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2.5 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Management

Criteria/Indication

Description

Expectant Management
  • Beta hCG < 1,500 IU/L
    And falling subsequent levels
  • No significant symptoms
  • Strong likelihood of spontaneous resolution
  • Monitoring without intervention, relying on the natural resolution of the ectopic pregnancy.

Medical Management
  • Beta hCG < 3,000 IU/L
  • Adnexal mass < 4 cm
  • No fetal cardiac activity
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Methotrexate (single dose/ multi-dose regimen) (best)
  • KCl (directly in sac)
  • Mifepristone
  • Prostaglandins

Surgical Management

(Option D)
  • Beta hCG > 5,000 IU/L
  • Size of ectopic > 4 cm
  • Presence of cardiac activity
  • Linear Salpingostomy (best)
  • Resection Anastomosis

questions.text: Arrange the following steps of dilation and curettage (D&C) in sequence: Serial dilation Curettage Uterine sound Assessment of uterine size and direction
Which of the following is not true about lupus nephritis in pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: Pregnancy should be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction

options.label: C
options.text: High-dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy are safe

options.label: D
options.text: Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, and azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: D. Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, and azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is not a suitable option for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP)?
questions.correct_answer: D. Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate
questions.explanation:
Trimester

Weeks

Medical Methods

Surgical Methods

Other Methods

First

Trimester

Up to 12 weeks

Mifepristone + Misoprostol (preferred method)
  • Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)
  • Not applicable

Second

Trimester

13-20 weeks

Misoprostol alone or with mifepristone

Dilation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Extra-amniotic Ethacridine Lactate Instillation
  • Hypertonic Saline or Urea Instillation

Third

Trimester

> 20 weeks

Rarely performed; typically involves induction of labor for therapeutic reasons.

Induction with prostaglandins (e.g., misoprostol)

Feticide procedures (e.g., intracardiac injection)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, who is pregnant for the second time, with one living child, and is at 18 weeks of gestation. She presents with a complaint of PV bleeding for the past 4 hours. On examination, her membranes are ruptured, and she is experiencing uterine contractions. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals a cervix that is shorter than 25 mm and funneling of the internal os by more than 1 cm. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics:
  • Painless dilation of the cervix in the 2nd trimester.
  • Characterised by spontaneous, painless dilation of the cervix followed by expulsion of products of conception.

Risk factors:
  • Past history of cervical surgeries such as LEEP, conization
  • Cervical trauma (during labour or instrumental delivery)
  • Congenital abnormality

Diagnosis:

History of pregnancy loss in 2nd trimester:

  • TVUS- investigation of choice
  • Normal shape and length of the cervix- T shaped and 3-4 cm
  • Cervical length ≤2.5 cm with one 2nd trimester painless abortion, then diagnosed as cervical insufficiency

Non-pregnant women:

If Hegar no. 8 dilator can be passed through internal os without any resistance

Management:

Progesterone and cervical cerclage placement.

Type

Cause

Investigations

Endocrinopathies

Hypothyroidism

TSH

Uncontrolled DM

Blood glucose levels/ HbA1c

Luteal phase defects

Progesterone levels in 2nd half

PCOS

Pelvic USG

Uterine
  • Cervical insufficiency
  • Uterine malformations
  • Submucous fibroids
  • Asherman syndrome

Pelvic USG/ TVUS/ Hysterosalpingography

Immunological

APLA syndrome

Lupus anticoagulant

Anticardiolipin antibody

Beta2 microglobulin antibody

Chromosomal

Translocation of chromosomes

Karyotyping of both parents

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument/procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used for termination of pregnancy up to 12 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Can be done on an OP basis

options.label: C
options.text: The capacity of the syringe is 30 ml

options.label: D
options.text: It created a negative pressure of 600 mmHg

questions.correct_answer: C. The capacity of the syringe is 30 ml
questions.explanation:
Uses of MVA Syringe

Use

Description

Pregnancy Termination
  • MVA syringes are commonly used for the termination of early pregnancies (up to 12 weeks).
  • The syringe is used to aspirate and remove the contents of the uterus.
  • It is a safe and effective method for induced abortion in appropriate settings.

Uterine Evacuation
  • MVA syringes are utilized for uterine evacuation in cases of incomplete miscarriage.
  • The syringe is used to remove retained products of conception from the uterus.

Endometrial Sampling
  • MVA syringes can be employed for endometrial sampling or biopsy procedures.
  • The syringe is used to collect a small sample of the endometrial tissue for diagnostic purposes.
  • It is commonly done to investigate abnormal uterine bleeding or to evaluate fertility issues.

Trimester

Procedure

Description

Image

1st

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
  • MVA is an outpatient surgical abortion procedure used up to 12 weeks of gestation.
  • The procedure involves dilating the cervix and inserting a cannula attached to a manual vacuum aspirator or a 60-mL syringe.
  • The cannula is used to remove retained tissue from the uterus.
  • The approximate pressure is around -610 mmHg.

Electric Vacuum Aspiration (EVA)
  • EVA is similar to MVA.
  • Instead of a manual syringe, it uses an electric pump to generate suction to remove retained products of conception.

 

Dilation and Curettage (D&C)

 
  • D&C is performed up to 12 weeks of gestation by dilating the cervix and using instruments like curettes and suction cannula.
  • MVA and EVA are preferred over sharp D&C for being safer and more efficient.

Karman’s cannula

 

Hegar’s dilator

 

Uterine curette

2nd

Dilation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • D&E is a 2nd-trimester abortion method involving cervical dilation using osmotic dilators. Ovum forceps are then used to remove the pregnancy tissue.
  • Draining amniotic fluid before removing the fetus is crucial to minimize the risk of amniotic fluid embolism during the procedure.

Ovum forceps

Hysterotomy

  • A hysterotomy is a surgical procedure where the uterus is incised to remove the fetus.
  • Reserved for 2nd-trimester abortions where other methods are not feasible or have failed.

options.label: A
options.text: Initial serum beta hCG level <200 mIU/mL

Management

Expectant Management

Medical Management

questions.text: The usage of the given device in the picture is:

options.label: B
options.text: Measure the length of the uterus

questions.explanation:
Karman Cannula

Definition

The Karman cannula, also known as the Karman curette, is a medical instrument used for suction-based procedures in gynecology.

Design

It is a slender, flexible, hollow tube with side perforations and a rounded tip for gentle insertion.

Uses

Mainly used for menstrual regulation (early pregnancy termination), endometrial sampling, and suction-based procedures in gynecology.

Procedure

1. The cannula is inserted into the uterine cavity through the cervix. 2. Vacuum suction is applied to aspirate uterine contents.

Advantages

Non-invasive, suitable for early pregnancy termination, less discomfort compared to some other methods.

Contraindications

Active pelvic inflammatory disease, septic abortion, ectopic pregnancy, certain uterine abnormalities.

Safety

Proper aseptic technique is crucial to prevent infection and complications.

Complications

Risks include infection, bleeding, uterine perforation, incomplete abortion, and pain.

Alternative Methods

Other methods include medical abortion (medication-induced) and surgical procedures (dilation and curettage).

Preparation

Patient counseling, informed consent, and appropriate pain management are essential.

Post-procedure Care

Monitoring for complications, providing pain relief, and advising on follow-up care.

questions.text: A woman, who is in her 8th week of pregnancy, has come seeking medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). What would be the correct dosage of misoprostol to be given through the mucosal route?

A 22-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks gestation comes to the ER with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting began one day back, and now the patient is unable to tolerate fluids. She complains of pain in the right upper quadrant, which started a few hours back. On examination, her temperature is 100.2 F, her pulse is 119 bpm, and her BP is 110/70 mm of Hg. She has swelling of her lower limbs up to the ankles bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows a gravid uterus corresponding to 10 weeks of gestation and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, with mild guarding and is diagnosed as acute appendicitis. What is the next step of management? Laboratory Findings: Complete blood count: Haemoglobin: 11g/dl Leukocytes: 13,000 cells/μl Platelets: 150,000 cells/μl Liver Function tests: AST: 40U/L ALT: 48U/L Urinalysis: Protein: negative Pus cells: 1-2/HPF Bacteria: none USG abdomen: Reveals a 9.7mm diameter, aperistaltic, non-compressible, dilated, blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum.
questions.explanation:
MANTRELS

Score

Migratory pain

1

Anorexia

1

Nausea, Vomiting

1

Tenderness

2

Rebound tenderness

1

Elevated temperature

1

Leukocytosis

2

Shift to left

1

Score Interpretation:

Score of 9-10 - diagnosis is certain

Score of 7-8 - High likely hood of diagnosis

Score of 5-6 - Equivocal (most dangerous)

CECT is indicated in cases of Equivocal MANTREL score findings to confirm the diagnosis

Score of 1-4 - Negative for acute appendicitis
